Genet. 2001; 27: 422-426Crossref PubMed Scopus (650) Google Scholar), the results suggest that germ cell isoforms will have an important role in directing meiotic or gametogenic patterns of gene expression, including the production of other germ cell-specific genes. However, there is still very little data on endogenous germ cell factors in reproductive tissues that would help understand their biochemical functions and their regulatory relationships with somatic factors. In this report we describe the characterization of ALF and TFIIA activities from the African clawed frog Xenopus laevis. As in mammals, we find that ALF is expressed in male germ cells of this organism. Unexpectedly, we also observe that ALF completely replaces TFIIA in immature oocytes in Xenopus females. The production of ALF compensates for the maternal storage and inactivation of TFIIAα/β mRNAs, thereby maintaining a constant level of a TFIIA-like activity. ALF activity is lost when oocytes undergo maturation and fertilization, and TFIIA reappears. Overall, the results reveal an interplay between ALF and TFIIA during germ cell development and early embryogenesis and suggest a model where ALF serves as a functional substitute for its somatic counterpart. Cloning—Partial Xenopus clones for ALF and TFIIA were identified by expressed sequence tag analysis (GenBank™ accession numbers BE188680, BE575947, AW767376, BE679537, and BM004702) and cloned by RT-PCR using Xenopus RNA. Maturation was induced with 2 μg/ml of progesterone (Sigma) and monitored by germinal vesicle breakdown (>95% GVBD). For preparation of embryos, the females were primed with 500 units of human chorionic gonadotropin (Sigma), and eggs were collected the next day for fertilization with minced testis (19Kay B.K. Peng H.B. Xenopus laevis: Practical Uses in Cell and Molecular Biology. Academic Press, San Diego, CA1991Google Scholar). Development was monitored according to Nieuwkoop and Faber (20Nieuwkoop P.D. Faber J. Normal Table of Xenopus laevis. Garland Publishing, New York1994Google Scholar). Identification of Multiple ALF and TFIIA Genes in Xenopus—Xenopus cDNAs for TFIIAα/β (TFIIAα/β1 and TFIIAα/β2), ALF, and TFIIAγ were identified by data base searches, RT-PCR, and sequence analysis (Fig. 1A). Although it is not clear whether TFIIAα/β1 and TFIIAα/β2 are functionally distinct, the presence of three large subunits (TFIIAα/β1, TFIIAα/ β2, and ALF) is the most observed in any organism to date. The 3′-UTR of TFIIAα/β1 predicts an unusual double-stranded stem that is not present in TFIIAα/β2 (Fig. 1A). In addition, comparison of the 3′-UTR from Xenopus TFIIAα/β with human TFIIAα/β revealed homology only within a ∼300-nucleotide region at the end. This module is very AU-rich and contains an AUUAAA poly(A) addition signal (Fig. 1B). ALF Replaces TFIIA in Immature Oocytes—Northern analysis showed ALF was expressed in both ovary and testis (Fig. 2A). This result revises the earlier conclusion that ALF is strictly testis-specific (5Upadhyaya A.B. Lee S.H. DeJong J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 18040-18048Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar, 6Ozer J. Moore P.A. Lieberman P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 122-128Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 8Han S. Zhou L. Upadhyaya A. Lee S.H. Parker K.L. DeJong J. Biol. Reprod. 2001; 64: 507-517Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar), suggesting instead that it might be involved in meiosis or another process that occurs in both male and female reproductive tissues. Like ALF, the TFIIAγ gene was highly expressed in testis and ovary but was also present at lower levels in somatic tissues. In contrast, TFIIAα/β was expressed to a high level in ovary and at reduced levels in other tissues. To determine whether ALF and TFIIA activities were present in the tissues predicted by the Northern results, TBP-dependent mobility shift assays were performed with the adeno-virus major late core promoter. The results showed that all of the tissues tested contained complexes that could be supershifted with an antibody that recognizes both ALF and TFIIA (Fig. 2B). Interestingly, the complex in ovary migrated slightly faster than those in somatic tissues, suggesting that it might contain ALF (7Upadhyaya A.B. Khan M. Mou T.-C. Junker M. Gray D.M. DeJong J. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 34208-34216Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). To test this possibility, mobility shift assays were performed with antibodies specific for the nonhomologous internal regions of ALF and TFIIAα/β. The complex in somatic tissues could be supershifted by the TFIIA-specific sera (Fig. 2C, lanes 1–6), showing that these contain TFIIA and were not supershifted with ALF-specific sera (lanes 7–12). In contrast, the complex in ovary and oocytes was supershifted only with ALF-specific sera (Fig. 2D, lanes 5–12). The results demonstrate the mutually exclusive expression of these two factors, with TFIIA restricted to somatic tissues and ALF completely replacing TFIIA in oocytes. Consistent with this observation, testis contained a major complex supershifted with TFIIA-specific sera and a minor complex supershifted with ALF-specific sera (Fig. 2D, lanes 1–4), presumably reflecting the mixed somatic and germ cell composition of this tissue. ALF and TFIIA Are Exchanged during Oocyte Maturation and Early Embryogenesis—The exclusive expression of ALF and TFIIA in oocytes and somatic tissues implies that they must be exchanged (TFIIA → ALF and ALF → TFIIA), probably at the onset of meiosis and again when embryonic cell divisions begin. In support of this idea, mobility shift assays of oocytes treated with progesterone to induce maturation showed that ALF activity fell by nearly 80% and TFIIA activity emerged (Fig. 3A). The transition was partially complete in eggs released by human chorionic gonadotropin-injected females and was finished in stage 10 embryos produced by in vitro fertilization (19Kay B.K. Peng H.B. Xenopus laevis: Practical Uses in Cell and Molecular Biology. Academic Press, San Diego, CA1991Google Scholar, 20Nieuwkoop P.D. Faber J. Normal Table of Xenopus laevis. Garland Publishing, New York1994Google Scholar) (Fig. 3B). Curiously, the switch begins prior to fertilization, continues during a period in which the zygote is transcriptionally silent and undergoing synchronized cell cleavages, and is complete at the mid-blastula transition when zygotic gene expression and asynchronous mitotic cell division begin (26Newport J. Kirschner M. Cell. 1982; 30: 687-696Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (789) Google Scholar). ALF was also present in oocytes as early as stage I (Fig. 3B), suggesting that the transition from TFIIA to ALF occurs prior to diplotene arrest, possibly in the pachytene stage of prophase I (8Han S. Zhou L. Upadhyaya A. Lee S.H. Parker K.L. DeJong J. Biol. Reprod. 2001; 64: 507-517Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). To elucidate the mechanism by which the transition in Fig. 3 (A and B) occurs, we characterized protein and RNA levels in detail. We first showed that ALF activity partially purified over a Q-Sepharose column cofractionated with immunoreactive bands corresponding to intact (70 kDa) and processed (α, 45 kDa; β, 30 kDa) species (Fig. 3C) (27DeJong J. Roeder R.G. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 2220-2234Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). During maturation the level of the ALFα and TFIIAα subunits correlated with ALF and TFIIA activity, respectively (Fig. 3, A and B, lower panels). RT-PCR analysis revealed that TFIIAα/β1, TFIIAα/β2, TFIIAγ, and ALF mRNAs were abundant in immature oocytes (Fig. 3D, lanes 1–5) and were roughly constant over the period of the transition (up to embryonic stage 6.5) (lanes 5–8). TFIIAα/β1, TFIIAα/β2, and TFIIAγ mRNAs continued to be present through embryonic stage 35/36 (lanes 9–12), whereas ALF mRNA diminished to undetectable levels by stage 10 (lane 9). The loss of ALF mRNA is consistent with the decline in factor activity. In contrast, the presence of TFIIAα/β mRNAs in immature oocytes was surprising because TFIIA activity was not present in these cells and suggested that these mRNAs might not be translated. TFIIAα/β mRNA Is Maternally Stored and Regulated by a Conserved 3′-UTR Module—To test whether TFIIAα/β mRNAs were sequestered into ribonucleoprotein particles and excluded from ribosomes, a hallmark of maternally stored transcripts, we centrifuged oocyte extracts over 20–60% nycodenz gradients (25Tafuri S.R. Wolffe A.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24255-24261Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Northern analysis of the recovered fractions showed that ALF was present in fractions 14–24 that contained ribosomal RNAs, whereas TFIIAα/β mRNAs was present in earlier fractions 11–13 (Fig. 4A). The results support the idea that TFIIA mRNA is stored and translationally inactive in immature oocytes. Sequences within the 3′-UTR of other mRNAs are known to play a role in regulating their translation (28Richter J.D. Microbiol. Mol. Biol. Rev. 1999; 63: 446-456Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), raising the possibility that the conserved 3′-UTR module within TFIIAα/β (Fig. 1) might have a similar role. To test this idea, we linked a luciferase reporter to the 3′-UTRs of TFIIAα/1, ALF, and a β-globin control (Fig. 4B) and injected transcribed mRNAs into control and progesterone-treated oocytes (22Liman E.R. Tytgat J. Hess P. Neuron. 1992; 9: 861-871Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (983) Google Scholar, 23De Moor C.H. Richter J.D. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 2294-2303Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar). The results showed that LUC-TFIIAα/β1 mRNA was repressed ∼6-fold in control oocytes compared with LUC-ALF or LUC-β-globin mRNAs and that the addition of a poly(A) tail prior to injection reversed this effect (Fig. 4B). When oocytes were induced to mature, translation of the LUC-TFIIAα/β1 mRNA increased 11-fold, whereas control constructs only increased ∼2.5-fold (Fig. 4B). The data show that the conserved 3′-UTR can regulate a heterologous reporter in a manner similar to that of the endogenous transcript. Translation of TFIIAα/β Is Associated with Polyadenylation—The maturation-dependent translation of maternal transcripts such as c-mos and cyclin B involves cytoplasmic polyadenylation and is required for meiotic progression (28Richter J.D. Microbiol. Mol. Biol. Rev. 1999; 63: 446-456Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). We therefore wanted to determine whether poly(A) extension of the conserved module in TFIIAα/β also occurred during maturation. 3′-UTR constructs from TFIIAα/β1, TFIIAα/β2, and a c-mos control (Fig. 5A) were transcribed in vitro in the presence of [32P]UTP and injected into oocytes (23De Moor C.H. Richter J.D. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 2294-2303Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar, 24Fox C.A. Sheets M.D. Wickens M.P. Genes Dev. 1989; 3: 2151-2162Crossref PubMed Scopus (271) Google Scholar). Each transcript was shifted to heterogeneous higher molecular weight species in maturing oocytes (Fig. 5B, lanes 1–6). Mutation of the ATTAAA poly(A) addition signal to AGCAAA completely abolished this modification (lanes 7–10), showing that it depends critically on this element and that the assay is sequence-dependent. To demonstrate that polyadenylation occurs on the endogenous transcript, we used rapid amplification of cDNA ends poly(A) test (21Salles F.J. Richards W.G. Strickland S. Methods. 1999; 17: 38-45Crossref PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar) to show extension of cellular TFIIAα/β1 mRNA (lanes 11 and 12). The results, together with the in vivo assays shown in Fig. 4B, confirm that control over TFIIA activity is mediated by the conserved 3′-UTR module and involves a maturation-dependent increase in the poly(A) tail. Interestingly, the Xenopus factors that mediate polyadenylation were also able to recognize and modify the conserved 3′-UTR from the human transcript (lanes 13 and 14), suggesting that translational regulation of this GTF might be conserved across species. Altered Levels of ALF and TFIIA Do Not Affect Oocyte Maturation—We wanted to know whether the switch from ALF to TFIIA was of direct importance for oocytes to advance through the maturation program. To test this question, we first showed that ALF and TFIIA subunits could be overexpressed in oocytes and that they would assemble into active factors. As determined by bandshift assays, the expression of TFIIA resulted in the appearance of a TFIIA-dependent TBP complex (Fig. 6A, lane 2). The amount of ALF complexes was unchanged when TFIIA was expressed, suggesting that the endogenous factor is quite stable. Expression of ALF caused a modest increase in ALF-dependent TBP complexes in immature oocytes (lane 5) and prevented the appearance of TFIIA that was normally observed when oocytes were treated with progesterone (lanes 4 and 6). Oocytes that overexpressed TFIIA showed no sign of early or accelerated maturation compared with control oocytes injected with water (Fig. 6B). Likewise, oocytes in which the appearance of TFIIA was prevented by overexpression of ALF also displayed maturation kinetics that were similar to controls. Thus, unlike factors such as c-mos and CPEB that have a direct influence on maturation, the exchange of TFIIA for ALF appears to be one of the many events that occur in anticipation of embryonic development. This observation is consistent with the fact that transcription is silenced during maturation and the fact that pre-existing pools of oocyte mRNA are sufficient for maturation even when transcription is inhibited (26Newport J. Kirschner M. Cell. 1982; 30: 687-696Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (789) Google Scholar). Inhibition of ALF Reduces Polymerase II-dependent Transcription in Oocytes—The replacement of ALF for TFIIA in immature oocytes predicts that it would play an essential role in RNA polymerase II-dependent transcription similar to that which TFIIA plays in somatic cells. To test this hypothesis, the ALF protein was inactivated in immature oocytes by the injection of affinity-purified ALF-specific antibodies. As judged by mobility shift assays, injection eliminated or supershifted nearly all the ALF-TBP-DNA complexes that were normally observed (Fig. 7A, lanes 4–6). When a thymidine kinase promoter-luciferase reporter construct was coinjected with the antibodies, transcription was reduced in an antibody dose-dependent fashion (Fig. 7B). Inhibition was factor-specific, because ALF antibodies could diminish TK promoter activity 11.1-fold, whereas an affinity-purified TFIIA-specific antibody reduced expression only 1.3-fold (Fig. 7C). ALF and TFIIA Have Opposite Effects on Transcription in Oocytes—To further establish the idea that ALF is an active replacement for TFIIA in oocytes, we asked whether overexpression would up-regulate transcription. ALF and TFIIAγ mRNAs were injected into oocytes and incubated for 12 h to allow for their production. Afterward, the oocytes were injected with the TK promoter construct to provide a platform for the assembly of an active preinitiation complex. The results showed that the activity of the luciferase reporter increased ∼3-fold under this protocol (Fig. 8). In contrast, activity was slightly reduced when TFIIAα/β or ALF antisense RNAs were injected and was unchanged when ALF RNA was injected (Fig. 8A). The results are consistent with the results of the immunodepletion experiments shown in Fig. 7 (B and C) and confirm that ALF is an active and positively acting transcription factor in oocytes. Earlier results had suggested that ALF and TFIIA were similar with respect to their ability to interact with TBP (7Upadhyaya A.B. Khan M. Mou T.-C. Junker M. Gray D.M. DeJong J. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 34208-34216Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar) and that both could support RNA polymerase II activity in vitro (5Upadhyaya A.B. Lee S.H. DeJong J. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 18040-18048Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar, 6Ozer J. Moore P.A. Lieberman P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 122-128Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Even though TFIIA is not normally present in oocytes, we wanted to evaluate whether it could function in this system. Surprisingly, overexpression of TFIIA caused luciferase activity to drop in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 8B). This result suggests that although TFIIA activates transcription in somatic cell systems, it fails to function properly in the context of an in vivo system composed of oocyte-specific transcription factors. This behavior provides at least one rationale for why it would be silenced during oogenesis and why ALF would be up-regulated. Taken together, the results of the immunodepletion and overexpression assays demonstrate that ALF is an RNA polymerase II transcription factor that compensates for the translational inactivation of TFIIA. The reciprocal expression of ALF and TFIIA maintains a constant supply of this GTF in transcriptionally active somatic and germ line tissues (Fig. 9). There are three major conclusions in this report. First, the expression patterns for ALF and TFIIA during Xenopus oogenesis shows that RNA polymerase II uses one set of factors in somatic cells and another set of factors in germ cells (Fig. 9). In particular, the results reveal that the role of TFIIA is assumed by ALF during meiosis but is returned to TFIIA once embryonic cell divisions begin. Thus, the germ cell-specific ALF isoform provides a functional substitute for the maternal storage and translational inactivation of the somatic TFIIA isoform. Interestingly, the mouse TAF1L gene is up-regulated during male germ cell development, presumably to compensate for meiotic inactivation of the X-linked somatic cell-specific TAFII250 gene (16Wang P.J. Page D.C. Hum. Mol. Genet. 2002; 11: 2341-2346Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar). It will be interesting to determine whether the transcriptional and translational control of separate genes or separate transcripts in germ cells will apply to all or only some of the core transcription factors. Second, the negative effect of the somatic factor TFIIA on the oocyte transcription machinery suggests that the germ cell transcription system is operationally distinct from the somatic system. Although previous studies have shown that ALF and TFIIA function in vitro and interact with TBP, the results here show that TFIIA represses the expression of a coinjected TK promoter construct in an in vivo system composed entirely of endogenous oocyte factors. Interestingly, germ cell-specific genes tend to evolve at a higher rate than somatic genes, and this includes ALF and TFIIA (8Han S. Zhou L. Upadhyaya A. Lee S.H. Parker K.L. DeJong J. Biol. Reprod. 2001; 64: 507-517Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). It is possible that rapidly coevolving germ cell factors have maintained a working complementarity and that the introduction of a factor optimized for the somatic cell system results in a failure to support PIC assembly and function. Other studies in which somatic and germ cell factors have been swapped, including those of ACE, tubulins, and TBP variants, have also revealed a basic and perhaps intentional incompatability between systems (29Moore P.A. Ozer J. Salunek M. Jan G. Zerby D. Campbell S. Lieberman P.M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7610-7620Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 30Teichmann M. Wang Z. Martinez E. Tjernberg A. Zhang D. Vollmer F. Chait B.T. Roeder R.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1999; 96: 13720-13725Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 31Kessler S.P. Rowe T.M. Gomos J.B. Kessler P.M. Sen G.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26259-26264Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar, 32Hoyle H.D. Raff E.C. J. Cell Biol. 1990; 111: 1009-1026Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). Third, the exchange of ALF and TFIIA during oocyte development in X. laevis is due to transcriptional control of ALF and translational control of TFIIAα/β. Transcriptional control of ALF in male germ cells of mice involves DNA methylation (33Xie W.S. Han S.Y. Khan M. DeJong J. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 17765-17774Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar), but we do not know whether this mechanism also controls its expression in oocytes. Translational control of TFIIA is mediated by polyadenylation of a discrete 3′-UTR module present in both the Xenopus TFIIAα/β1 and TFIIAα/β2 transcripts. The relatively large size of the module (∼300 nucleotides) suggests that its function may depend on CPE elements or other sites for RNA-binding proteins and perhaps on the formation of a particular secondary structure. This module is similar to one in human TFIIAα/β, raising the possibility that translational regulation of these and perhaps other pairs of germ and somatic cell GTFs (including TFIIAγ; see Ref. 34Kashiwabara S.-I. Noguchi J. Zhuang T. Ohmura K. Honda A. Sugiura S. Miyamoto K. Takahashi S. Inoue K. Ogura A. Baba T. Science. 2002; 298: 1999-2002Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar) might be a phylogenetically conserved mechanism for controlling transcription factor activity. Like TFIIA, TBP is also absent from Xenopus oocytes (35Veenstra G.J.C. Destree O.H.J. Wolffe A.P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7972-7982Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar, 36Bell P. Scheer U. Exp. Cell Res. 1999; 248: 122-135Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). Thus, transcription in these cells might rely on a core promoter recognition complex composed of ALF, TLF/TRF2, or other factors. In fact, transcription factor variants in Drosophila (TRF2/TLF) and mouse (TAFII105) associate with proteins different from those that associate with TBP (15Freiman R.N. Albright S.R. Zheng S. Sha W.C. Hammer R.E. Tjian R. Nature. 2001; 293: 2084-2087Google Scholar, 37Hochheimer A. Zhou S. Zheng S. Holmes M.C. Tjian R. Nature. 2002; 420: 439-445Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar). Given that TFIIA plays a role in the control of cell cycle regulated genes in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (38Ozer J. Lezina L.E. Ewing J. Audi S. Lieberman P.M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 2559-2570Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 39Upadhyaya A.B. DeJong J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2003; 1625: 88-97Crossref PubMed Scopus (2) Google Scholar), it may be that ALF- and TFIIA-containing complexes have specific roles in the meiotic and mitotic cell cycle programs, respectively. The expression of new core promoter-associated transcription factor factors might also be related to the changes in DNA packaging and nuclear architecture that occur during germ cell development (40Sassone-Corsi P. Science. 2002; 296: 2176-2178Crossref PubMed Scopus (366) Google Scholar). Experiments to address these issues will be an important focus of future studies. In conclusion, our work here shows that gene expression during oogenesis involves the mutually exclusive expression and translationally regulated exchange of germ- and somatic cell-specific GTFs. Prompted by the reported lack of solvation effects on the oxygen affinity of fish (trout I) hemoglobin that questioned allosteric water binding in human hemoglobin A (Bellelli, A., Brancaccio, A., and Brunori, M. (1993) J. Biol. Chem. 268, 4742–4744), we have investigated solvation effects in fish and human hemoglobins by means of the osmotic stress method and allosteric analysis. In contrast to the earlier report, we demonstrate that water potential does affect oxygen affinity of trout hemoglobin I in the presence of inert solutes like betaine. Moreover, we show that upon oxygenation electrophoretically anodic hemoglobin from trout and eel bind a similar number of water molecules as does human hemoglobin A, whereas the cathodic hemoglobins of trout and eel bind smaller, but mutually similar, numbers of water molecules. Addition of cofactors strongly increases the number of water molecules bound to eel hemoglobin A (as in human hemoglobin) but only weakly affects water binding to eel hemoglobin C. Despite extensive data on the water sensitivity of human HbA, very little is known about how water affects oxygen binding in other tetrameric vertebrate Hbs. Fish Hbs that show a remarkably broad range of oxygen binding properties and allosteric effects and are well characterized from functional and structural points of view (7Brunori M. Curr. Top. Cell Regul. 1975; 9: 1-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar, 8di Prisco G. Tamburrini M. Comp. Biochem. Physiol. B. 1992; 102: 661-671Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar) are excellent candidates for such analysis. In contrast to mammals that often have only one major Hb component, fish commonly have several isoHbs with marked functional differentiation, indicating an in vivo division of labor to ensure adequate O2 loading and unloading under various physiological and environmental conditions (7Brunori M. Curr. Top. Cell Regul. 1975; 9: 1-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar). Fish Hbs fall into two major categories (9Feuerlein R.J. Weber R.E. J. Comp. Physiol. B. 1996; 165: 597-606Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar) based on their electrophoretical mobility at alkaline pH: 1) anodic Hbs found in all fish, whose oxygen affinities are strongly decreased by heterotropic ligands such as protons (Bohr and Root effects) and organic phosphates, and 2) cathodic Hbs encountered in eels, salmonids, and catfish, which show no or little Bohr and highly variable phosphate effects. Because of their higher O2 affinities and lower pH sensitivities, the cathodic Hbs are well suited for O2 transport under hypoxic, hypercapnic, or acidotic conditions (9Feuerlein R.J. Weber R.E. J. Comp. Physiol. B. 1996; 165: 597-606Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). However, the agreement between Δnw values calculated by the two equations may not be uniquely related to the absence of solute binding, as indicated by the similar values for eel HbA, which shows apparent oxygen-linked solute binding in the presence of GTP + KCl (Table I). Only ∼25 additional water molecules bind to human HbA during the deoxy to oxy transition in the absence of anions, in contrast to ∼72 molecules in the presence of saturating levels of Cl– or 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (3Colombo M.F. Seixas F.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 11741-11748Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). The discrepancy of 45–50 water molecules was ascribed either to local dehydration of the anion binding site upon complex formation or to global change in the protein conformation induced by anion binding, although a release of 45–50 water molecules was assumed to be too large an effect to be attributed only to the reorganization of bound water molecules at the phosphates binding site (3Colombo M.F. Seixas F.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 11741-11748Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). Our value of 42–43 water molecules that are bound to human HbA during oxygenation is intermediate between the values of ∼25 molecules found for stripped, deionized HbA in weak (10 mm Hepes) buffer (3Colombo M.F. Seixas F.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 11741-11748Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar) and ∼60–70 found for HbA (1Colombo M.F. Rau D.C. Parsegian V.A. Science. 1992; 256: 655-659Crossref PubMed Scopus (330) Google Scholar) in 0.1 m NaCl and 0.05 m Tris buffer, suggesting sensitivity to different buffer conditions. We here show that the physiological effectors GTP and Cl– increase the number of water molecules bound to eel HbA from 40–43 in stripped Hb to 118–129 (Table I). The structural basis for this increase in hydration is not known or whether the increase can be related to the strong phosphate and pH effects observed in anodic fish Hbs. The cathodic fish Hbs studied here (trout HbI and eel HbC) analogously respond to an increase in water activity with an increased oxygen binding, indicating preferential binding of water molecules to the R state. These Hbs bind a mutually similar but smaller number of water molecules than the anodic Hbs during the deoxy to oxy transition (∼17–31, when betaine is used as solute; Table I) despite marked differences in their sensitivity to organic phosphates, which is lacking in trout HbI and pronounced in eel HbC (9Feuerlein R.J. Weber R.E. J. Comp. Physiol. B. 1996; 165: 597-606Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar, 25Giardina B. Giacometti G.M. Coletta M. Brunori M. Giacometti G. Rigatti G. Biochem. J. 1978; 175: 407-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). Bellelli et al. (18Bellelli A. Brancaccio A. Brunori M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 4742-4744Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) have previously shown that addition of sucrose to trout HbI solutions had no effect on oxygen binding, suggesting that trout HbI may be insensitive to changes in water activity. To test this, we examined the effects of sucrose and of betaine, which is the solute least likely among a range of tested solutes to interact with protein surfaces (20Courtenay E.S. Capp M.W. Anderson C.F. Record Jr., M.T. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 4455-4471Crossref PubMed Scopus (384) Google Scholar). In agreement with the observation of Bellelli et al. (18Bellelli A. Brancaccio A. Brunori M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 4742-4744Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), trout HbI showed almost no response to varying sucrose concentrations but did show similar responses as the other tetrameric Hbs investigated in the presence of betaine, binding ∼17–31 additional water molecules upon oxygenation (Fig. 2; Table I). The results obtained with betaine may thus represent a general response to changes in water activity among tetrameric Hbs. A possible explanation for the lack of a water effect in trout HbI in the presence of sucrose may be that sucrose has a 2-fold effect on this Hb, one on water activity (stabilizing the R state) and one on the dielectric constant of the medium (stabilizing the T state; Ref. 18Bellelli A. Brancaccio A. Brunori M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 4742-4744Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). These two effects may act in opposite directions and obliterate each other. This can be compared with the Cl– effect on human HbA that involves both direct interaction with the protein and an indirect effect exerted through a change in water activity (26Colombo M.F. Rau D.C. Parsegian V.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 10517-10520Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 27Rand R.P. Parsegian V.A. Rau D.C. Cell Mol. Life Sci. 2000; 57: 1018-1032Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). Sucrose and Cl– would thus be poor choices for investigating osmotic stress in trout HbI or human HbA, respectively. In contrast to trout HbI, sucrose and betaine have superimposable effects on trout HbIV and are in this case inert solutes. Sucrose, glycerol, and glucose also have superimposable effects on the oxygen affinity of the clam Scapharca inaequivalvis HbI (28Royer Jr., W.E. Pardanani A. Gibson Q.H. Peterson E.S. Friedman J.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 14526-14531Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar), supporting the view that the apparent sucrose insensitivity in trout HbI is due to specific properties of this Hb molecule. The highly consistent results obtained with betaine in the proteins investigated here confirm the inference of Courtenay et al. (20Courtenay E.S. Capp M.W. Anderson C.F. Record Jr., M.T. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 4455-4471Crossref PubMed Scopus (384) Google Scholar) that betaine may be the most appropriate solute in osmotic stress experiments and in protein hydration studies. In studies on solvation effects in proteins, differences in the size of the solvent-accessible area between conformational states are determining factors (1Colombo M.F. Rau D.C. Parsegian V.A. Science. 1992; 256: 655-659Crossref PubMed Scopus (330) Google Scholar). An interesting feature of trout HbI is that compared with human HbA it has a larger buried surface area in the R state than in the T state (17Tame J.H. Wilson J.C. Weber R.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 259: 749-760Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). Nevertheless it binds water molecules upon oxygenation, albeit to a lesser extent than human HbA. This indicates that factors other than surface accessible area influences protein hydration. One possibility is that upon oxygenation of trout HbI the ratio of polar to hydrophobic amino acid surface residues increases even though the overall solvent-accessible area decreases. Taken together, human and anodic and cathodic fish Hbs show similar overall sensitivities to changes in water activity despite the diversity in their pH and phosphate effects. This suggests that the amino acid residues responsible for allosteric effects, such as the Bohr effect and phosphate and anion sensitivities, do not necessarily contribute to water sensitivity. This seems logical because water sensitivity may be expected to rely on the presence/absence of hydrophilic residues on the protein surface, whereas the requirements for Bohr groups are more stringent and relate to their precise spatial distribution and changes in proton binding affinity in response to ligand binding. In the highly phosphate-sensitive eel HbC, addition of GTP and KCl does not alter the allosteric water binding, suggesting that the central cavity at the phosphate-binding site does not contribute to differential hydration between T and R states (Fig. 4). This is the opposite of anodic eel HbA where addition of allosteric cofactors increases the number of water molecules bound upon oxygenation almost 3-fold (Fig. 3; Table I), resembling the situation in human HbA discussed above. As also concluded by Colombo and Seixas (3Colombo M.F. Seixas F.A. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 11741-11748Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar), it seems unlikely that this strong interplay between allosteric anions and water binding should reflect reorganization of bound water molecules at the anion binding sites alone and may reflect more radical conformational changes. Clearly, some basic structural differences seem to exist in phosphate-induced conformational changes between eel Hbs C and A. In conclusion, we show that all the tetrameric Hbs investigated here respond to an increase in water activity by stabilizing the R state conformation and that the number of oxygen-linked water molecules is similar among anodic Hbs (human HbA, eel HbA, and trout HbIV) and among cathodic ones (eel HbC and trout HbI), ∼43 and ∼17–31, respectively. The only data on fish Hbs that hitherto were available (showing absence of hydration effects on trout HbI, Ref. 18Bellelli A. Brancaccio A. Brunori M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 4742-4744Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) thus cannot be considered representative of fish Hbs and may have been influenced by the specific experimental conditions and solute choice.
